data.title: Soft wrap inserts blank line if no obvious place to break
data.body:
There is a bug when the line has no obvious point to break:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/30030/6678452/dc882384-cc9f-11e4-84ee-27dad2bcebe5.png)

This relates to PR #5567

data.title: Deprecate all on-based event registration
data.body: I noticed bracket matcher was still calling `TextEditor::on` for a `destroyed` event and not getting a deprecation warning for it.

data.title: Make One Dark the default UI/syntax themes
data.body: Closes #5173

data.title: Running "atom <path>" opens folder twice in tree view
data.body:
When I use `atom <path>` from the command line to open a folder in a new atom window it shows two instances of that folder in the tree view. Example: `atom C:\Code\Go\src\bosun.org` starts a new atom window with two bosun.org folders in the tree view:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/304401/6677181/3334fa34-cbf3-11e4-9275-94e91798ecce.png)

Tested on Windows 8.1 using Atom 0.183.0

data.title: Why is there no setTextInScreenRange TextEditor API method ?
data.body:
Hope this is the right place for this issue. :sweat_smile:

If there is an [TextEditor API](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.187.0/TextEditor) method usually comes in both the screen and the buffer "falvor", but for [setTextInBufferRange](https://atom.io/docs/api/v0.187.0/TextEditor#instance-setTextInBufferRange) there is only the buffer version. 

Because of this, I have to convert all my coordinates to buffer coordinates, whereas editor coordinates made more sense and it was more convenient in this case.

Why is there no setTextInScreenRange ? Is the documentation incomplete? Is there a reason behind this ? Or will this probably be added later on ? 

Thank you!

data.title: The insanity of Unicode's "RTL override"
data.body:
This is a bug report mostly based on [this neat article](http://habrahabr.ru/post/252813/). I'll summarize the essence that relates to Atom, right here. Consider this snippet of Python:

``` python
def maps():
    print "maps maps maps"

def spam():
    print "Erasing everything..."
    print "done."

s = "spam‮" ,spam ,"‬spam"
# ^ attention to this line: try selecting it with your mouse
s[1]()
```

That line, properly escaped:

``` python
s = "spam‮" ,spam ,"‬spam"
```

The symbols of interest, in order of appearance, are `‮` or RLO (right-to-left override) and `‬` or PDF (pop directional formatting). They, respectively, reverse text direction and set it back.

Atom expands this combination just like a browser would, it actually displays that RLO-PDF piece in reverse. However, interaction with it is... awkward. Start with the fact that you can't (at least visually) move your cursor inside that gap in any way.

Look at this. With "Plain text" grammar on, I've selected that line:

![Screenshot](http://i.imgur.com/q6KKB0M.png)

Noticed that? 10 units of extra space. Notice also, that between RLO and PDF are exactly 10 characters. That's a hint. However, once I switch on Python grammar (and RLO-PDF interval is now contained in multiple elements), things get even more awkward.

![Screenshot 2](http://i.imgur.com/QpOpCDm.png)

Not 10 units, as before. Now we have only 4. And from that moment, I don't have a slightest clue about what's going on, but something needs to be done about that.

This needs a discussion. I can immediately come up with these two general directions:
1. Interpret as designed in Unicode. Fix the UI, make the cursor work properly and not introduce gaps like the ones above.
2. Represent Unicode control characters with some sort of "placeholders" and don't let them act as designed in Unicode.

Personally, I stand for placeholders, as Atom is mostly a code editor, and code is a raw sequence of characters. It makes sense for Atom to display it as closely as possible to how the parser will see it.

In those cases when plain text is used to author a document that makes use of these sequences to display properly, "preview" plugins come into play and let you preview the document as it will look after processing.

Thoughts?

data.title: Clipboard shortcuts on Windows are from DOS 6.x
data.body: Copy / Cut / Paste should be Ctrl-C/X/V, the current shortcuts are the super-old DOS shortcuts for these operations (which should also work, but the above ones definitely should too)

On my Dell XPS 13 9343 (2015) atom's menus are very ... unreadable.
![capture d ecran de 2015-03-16 21 30 49](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2241520/6675829/bcf7b43e-cc23-11e4-8363-407d07154211.png)

data.title: cannot disable packages in safe mode
data.body:
I can't load atom in anything but safe mode presumably because of a bad package.  Unfortunately I can't use package-cop because it doesn't work in safe mode.

I went to the settings page to disable packages.  There were two problems ...

1) When I scroll down, go into settings for a package, I can't go back, can I?.  I have to click on packages again and start at the top.  This is a serious problem when you have 100 packages.

2) All enabled packages show the `Install` button which makes no sense.  And since there  is no `Settings` button I can't disable anything.

I'll use the command-line but that is a lot of typing. The above problems need fixing.

windows 8.1
atom 187

data.title: Support HTML-first workflow
data.body:
Google Polymer takes an "HTML-first" approach to defining custom elements. Rather than calling a JavaScript method to register an element, you instead use a custom `<polymer-element>` tag to declare elements. The Polymer team had difficulty using this approach in Atom for a couple of reasons.
### Issues running inline scripts due to our content-security policy

This is the biggest hurdle. There's currently no way to white-list script tags in an imported HTML document. A content security policy can be associated with a nonce value that can be inserted into scripts to indicate they are runnable, and it would be nice if we could cascade this nonce through an HTML import to script tags in the imported content.
### Needing to manually insert HTML-imports into the `<head>`

This is easily solvable via a service that presents a function like `loadHTMLDocument(fullPath)`. I'd rather do it with `require`, but Node-style requires are expected to be synchronous and waiting for the imported content to load is async. This would therefore still require a tiny bit of boilerplate in `activate` to interact with the service and load the package's main document.

data.title: Lint package builds on Travis
data.body:
We currently have coffee linting set up to run on core CI builds but package CI builds don't have this.

This causes problems where green PRs get merged on packages but they fail when updated in core since the lint task fails.

data.title: Disappearing package option
data.body:
I've discovered this issue with [atom-terminal](https://github.com/karan/atom-terminal) package. When package option (args, for example) is empty, then in config.cson we see no "args" parameter. After atom restart we will not see "Args" parameter at all. If whe write something like "foo" for this parameter, then line "args: 'foo'" appears in config.cson. So, I think it's about dealing with empty parameters or something like this.
So, before:
![screenshot - 16 03 2015 - 14 21 10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2385765/6665254/4a82744c-cbe8-11e4-8e5b-2c73e69543a0.png)
![screenshot - 16 03 2015 - 14 22 05](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2385765/6665253/4a812902-cbe8-11e4-8546-df85825a0b18.png)
After:
![screenshot - 16 03 2015 - 14 22 42](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2385765/6665255/4a861ec6-cbe8-11e4-8ab5-3846273e9843.png)
![screenshot - 16 03 2015 - 14 24 03](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2385765/6665257/4a88e2a0-cbe8-11e4-98b1-ad4e59809aa6.png)
After restart:
![screenshot - 16 03 2015 - 14 25 00](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2385765/6665256/4a879d14-cbe8-11e4-9d16-42f0d28cfa90.png)

data.title: PHP syntax mixup
data.body:
Latest Atom version 0.187.0 (on OS X) does not highlight the following PHP code correctly:

`$cvsData = date("Y-m-d H:i:s") . ";" . $_POST["venue"] . ";" . $_POST["salutation"] . ";" . $_POST["surname"] . ";" . $_POST["name"] . ";" . $_POST["company"] . ";" . $_POST["phone"] . ";" . $_POST["email"] . ";" . $_POST["address"] . ";" . $_POST["plz"] . ";" . $_POST["place"] . "\n";`

It stops inking the variables starting with $_POST["phone"].

![bildschirmfoto 2015-03-16 um 06 28 13](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4235935/6661029/a9d153a2-cba5-11e4-9547-83c739f68597.png)

data.title: incorrect cursor placement on lines with accented characters
data.body:
There seems to have been a recent regression in the placement of the cursor and end-of-line marker on lines with accented characters. For example 

ὤὤὤὤὤὤὤὤὤὤ

Has ten _characters_ but if you ctrl-E to the end of the line the cursor is in the wrong place:

![screen shot 2015-03-15 at 5 18 12 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/24426/6658154/54d492a6-cb37-11e4-88da-f370ee0b9d59.png)

This may seem obscure but is making it very difficult to use Atom for natural language processing applications with non-ASCII character sets. It worked fairly recently so is likely a recent regression.

data.title: Improve brace matching
data.body:
Brace matching in ATOM is like this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103348/6656256/f2c59dde-cb23-11e4-9d61-16c3cc9c43e3.png)

In e.g. Php Storm, brace matching prioritizes parens based on their direction - like this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103348/6656258/15b2e4dc-cb24-11e4-9617-a81e7ba765dc.png)

Why this is better: because, regardless of whether the cursor is over an opening or closing brace, it's matched in such a way that you're typing _outside_ the matching parens - consistently.

The way it works in ATOM currently, if I start typing in the first example, I'm typing on the outside of the matched parens - but if I start typing in the second example, I'm typing inside the matched parens. 

Having to cursor right before you start typing after a closing brace, and then having the "wrong" parens highlight when you do, is really confusing.

data.title: Use core:cancel command to dissmiss notifications
data.body: Listen to `core:cancel` on `atom-workspace`. When triggered dismiss notifications.

data.title: Don't deselect text when searching "Only in selection" if nothing is found, please!
data.body:
Repro: highlight some text, search for something which is not found within the text, and become frustrated when you have to re-highlight a potentially very long set of lines to try searching for something slightly different!

Ideally, the selection wouldn't change even if it **did** find something, but it would just highlight the found items in some way instead.

data.title: Appmenu / Global menu does not work on Kubuntu 14.04
data.body:
When running atom (version 0.186.0) in KDE  (4.14.2 from Kubuntu 14.04) with the global menubar enabled, the menu is displayed, but does not work - clicking on any item does nothing, e.g. selecting 'Open File' from the 'File' menu does nothing. 

Moreover, when I quit atom, the plasma-desktop (the main KDE desktop process) crashes. 
This might indicate, that it is a bug in KDE, but I don't know how to figure this out.

Atom version: 0.186.0
OS: Kubuntu 14.04
KDE: 4.14.2

data.title: Add pane:close to atom-pane context menu
data.body: I've found myself wanting to do this quite frequently – this PR adds "Close Pane" to `atom-pane`'s context menu, allowing you to close the active pane from the context menu just like you can do with the "Split" pane commands.

data.title: Select option in autocomplete
data.body: its very weird to select option shown in autocomplete only my mouse. what key do i need to make use of to select option suggested. i am making use of "enter" key, but it does not work. is it expected behaviour or caused by some external community plugin ?

data.title: Three finger tap for definitions doesn't work on OS X
data.body:
In a Mac text view or web view, when you three finger tap a word it becomes yellow and a popover window with definitions (from country specific dictionaries and wikipedia) appears. Not so in atom.
I find this very annoying since I use that feature a lot. I'm not sure if this is a bug or a feature request since it is standard in all (not strictly) other similar apps.
